document.title: Pennsylvania Assessment Anchors and Eligible Content

6EB1DDA42CCD459EB0641AAE9F0E7078.description: Provide a concluding section related to the analysis presented.

DC0F2865AB764CD090ABBFED2BA36D6C.description: Establish and maintain a formal style.

257FC2881860489089A13FB35D559B14.description: Use precise language and domain-specific vocabulary to inform about or explain the topic and/or convey the experience and events.

462AE71AB854470288DCDFDA56FEAB99.description: Link ideas within and across categories of information using words, phrases, and clauses (e.g., in contrast, especially).

E0FEC4A2D78A4AC8972FEFF33D529952.description: Develop the analysis using a variety of evidence from text(s) to support claims, opinions, ideas, and inferences.

F8833D0DEE4A4744B54A266A737C1457.description: Introduce text(s) for the intended audience, state an opinion and/or topic, establish a situation, and create an organizational structure in which ideas are logically grouped to support the writer’s purpose.

D9E80940EF0242899B098F6F0EC99520.description: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and/or research.

A9BBC43C04014B7FA6C079E4378A713E.description: Choose words and phrases for effect.*

61C6A1EFC6424DED9F393DF7B92ADA29.description: Choose words and phrases to convey ideas precisely.*

3DA6774B41FC46EDA771EF5239D38FA3.description: Expand, combine, and reduce sentences for meaning, reader/listener interest, and style.

74F8695385FE4F7080B1214CA0D7D254.description: Use knowledge of language and its conventions.

C3403B8E64DF4B539E311E1CF2B9AD45.description: Use underlining, quotation marks, or italics to indicate titles of works.

2C9B87CBBDFF4E48ABA2508C60208A92.description: Use a comma to set off the words yes and no (e.g., Yes, thank you), to set off a tag question from the rest of the sentence (e.g., It’s true, isn’t it?), and to indicate direct address (e.g., Is that you, Steve?).

977E0B241087431E8CB8CF975024A76B.description:
Use a comma to separate an introductory element
from the rest of the sentence.

D0B5E9C2719E42059720C4C4206A506A.description: Use punctuation to separate items in a series.*

D1C04A83E21A4DA1A6698DC51728CA86.description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling.

E78966FEB2C54794985B990F3B04D816.description: Correctly use frequently confused words (e.g., to, too, two; there, their, they’re).*

345FDD7EDEB849E4A38F36B9CF872124.description: Produce complete sentences, recognizing and correcting inappropriate fragments and run-on sentences.*

9C2979259DAA4529B47E7E02028AB96F.description: Recognize and correct inappropriate shifts in verb tense.*

D77B723E2F8D46FDB48AC83873EAC624.description: Use verb tense to convey various times, sequences, states, and conditions.

16365F4B79FB4EDDB45DAFEDEFC5815A.description: Form and use the perfect verb tenses (e.g., I had walked; I have walked; I will have walked).

C1050806875D4C37A955FF331D94F303.description: Explain the function of conjunctions, prepositions, and interjections in general and their function in particular sentences.

646D94D040DB4403A9CA76B6A1A05DF0.description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage.

508B757878754DC989784E563CE94972.description: Provide a conclusion that follows from the narrated experiences or events.

0CA68B96626D4008B79ABD4595FD12FB.description: Use concrete words and phrases and sensory details to convey experiences and events precisely.

F01DC502900F4142A56ED4DD50BF47CA.description: Use a variety of transitional words, phrases, and clauses to manage the sequence of events.

4FB6D12222694787867A6C389DE2DA77.description: Use narrative techniques, such as dialogue, description, and pacing, to develop experiences and events or to show the responses of characters to situations.

3A5E9AEEE70B471CB15B6016371F05AC.description: Orient the reader by establishing a situation and introducing a narrator and/or characters; organize an event sequence that unfolds naturally to support the writer’s purpose.

2B8E8BFC71CC46D7B7E8C7CE3B9980FA.description: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, descriptive details, and clear event sequences.

736ADDDB8F3D4E58B6EBC14BF2F920D3.description:
Provide a concluding section related to the
information or explanation presented.

F0AA78399D75451E9325AB80E6335F44.description: Establish and maintain a formal style.

50DB383F834949A98545F59438EA91CC.description: Use precise language and domain-specific vocabulary to inform about or explain the topic.

C09A57C635CD4D2C953FEEC3786629B8.description: Link ideas within and across categories of information using words, phrases, and clauses (e.g., in contrast, especially).

62F9DB4D42B0425E9C9A62454A7F3B75.description: Develop the topic with facts, definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples related to the topic.

52364A09B94847859D5AC207E721C9DE.description: Introduce a topic for the intended audience, provide a general observation and focus, and group related information logically to support the writer’s purpose.

647B4DAAA0A8400FA3405A3D5F9DE31C.description: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas and information clearly.

572980EAB76F425FA619277975F37E38.description: Provide a concluding section related to the opinion presented.

B7BCF4F1F75F4F42971C7A1F2F13347A.description: Establish and maintain a formal style.

D9F90978B4784A87B8F4C4764A041062.description: Link opinion and reasons using words, phrases, and clauses (e.g., consequently, specifically).

44C4BDFC84004BBE8DD83A2587DAFFD4.description: Provide logically ordered reasons that are supported by facts and details.

CBB37CF2E10F41098FECE9E5FFAC8140.description: Introduce a topic or text for the intended audience, state an opinion, and create an organizational structure in which ideas are logically grouped to support the writer’s purpose.

F2A7AD3000664E2CBA49304D62C7B4CB.description: Write opinion pieces on topics or texts, supporting a point of view with reasons and information.

896F3F6870794C7A89B84C7E47A0182D.description:
Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.a. Interpret figurative language (simile, metaphor, and personification) in context.
b. Recognize and explain the meaning of common idioms, adages, and proverbs.
c. Use the relationship between particular words (e.g., synonyms, antonyms, homographs) to better understand each of the words.

691A78F8970242F1A0DB6672C519EB6F.description:
Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 5 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies. a. Use context (e.g., cause/effect relationships and comparisons in text) as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.
b. Use common, grade-appropriate Greek and Latin affixes and roots as clues to the meaning of a word (e.g., photograph, photosynthesis).
c. Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases used in a text.

FBC00F72D1544FFA9715D2AAFABC9965.description: Demonstrate understanding of vocabulary and figurative language in informational texts

9C85E18D21FD49589508C31B0633371C.description: Interpret text features (e.g., headings, graphics, charts) and/or make connections between text and the content of text features.

5883DDAE9E6D48E4A28BBF8DC01FDA99.description: Integrate information from several texts on the same topic in order to demonstrate subject knowledge.

286C2F32AEDC4DD888113EDF7658CBEE.description: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text, identifying which reasons and evidence support which point(s).

03596C98136647F2B03E542B21718F57.description: Demonstrate understanding of connections within, between, and/or among informational texts.

693AA7B6EDA04C5190C865712F13ABE3.description: Compare and contrast the overall structure (e.g., chronology, comparison, cause/effect, problem/solution) of events, ideas, concepts, or information and text features in two or more texts

BD38692F5521485897E0BE797C1CB912.description: Analyze multiple accounts of the same event or topic, noting important similarities and differences in the point of view they represent.

8D2548E3A6054279A7403EDDD9C341B9.description: Demonstrate understanding of craft and structure in informational texts.

C0404A2FE004487F84995C918D870D00.description: Explain the relationships or interactions between two or more individuals, events, ideas, steps, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text based on specific information in the text.

DBC250844CDF44ECACD6E34F917120A9.description: Determine two or more main ideas of a text and explain how they are supported by key details; summarize the text.

A90406CABF6949D89173E03824DE82AA.description: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences and/or making generalizations from the text.

DC3C349943E44C7596D0EA366E8288F9.description: Demonstrate understanding of key ideas and details in informational texts.

79E0C4A45ED94069AE3BF2CA4C432206.description: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings. a. Interpret figurative language (e.g., simile, metaphor, personification) in context. b. Recognize and explain the meaning of common idioms, adages, and proverbs. c. Use the relationship between particular words (e.g., synonyms, antonyms, homographs) to better understand each of the words.

5C05E6271F03489495090F0FDF9EEFBF.description:
Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 5 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies. a. Use context (e.g., cause/effect relationships and comparisons in text) as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.
b. Use common, grade-appropriate Greek and Latin affixes and roots as clues to the meaning of a word (e.g., photograph, photosynthesis).

F36AA8FE476C452E927A34DD37FEE0DB.description: Demonstrate understanding of vocabulary and figurative language in literature.

53BABB85B8404AE5A67BF1165FA659EB.description: Compare and contrast stories in the same genre on their approaches to similar themes and topics.

101328870992428DBB0F346A79D91177.description: Demonstrate understanding of connections within, between, and/or among texts.

114A86D3A45B4D468ABDA98B4F4F4940.description: Describe how a narrator’s or speaker’s point of view influences how events are described; describe an author’s purpose and explain how it is conveyed in the text.

F1A2726D9CF44CC299576FC5B38D62D9.description: Demonstrate understanding of craft and structure in literature.

A02CEF6710B44B3B912827B7D04C930F.description: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story, drama, or poem, drawing on specific details in the text .

61E46C3833764871935EE732EB1F0647.description: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text, including how characters in a story or drama respond to challenges or how the speaker in a poem reflects upon a topic; summarize the text.

6B73E43B98F9415FA0991B6A52DDEFEE.description: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences and/or making generalizations from the text.

E65994B467F54890931C9AB867D50FF7.description: Demonstrate understanding of key ideas and details in literature.
